body:
ptgoetz:

Eliminating 0MQ/JZMQ is also necessary due to its LGPL license. The 0MQ transport can be made available, but need to be a separate project outside of apache.

ptgoetz:

A pull request is now available: https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/pull/766

ptgoetz:

Pull request available: https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/pull/767

azaroth:

Pull request available:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-storm/pull/2

ptgoetz:

Fixed for 0.9.1
Thanks for moving this over to the Apache repo!
A change that ad releases this has already been committed. Would you mind closing the pull request?
+1 for now. Before releasing we'll need to move to a non-snapshot release.

+1

Out of curiosity, what version of lein are you running? I've built dozens of times and never hit that error.

I was using `Leiningen 2.0.0 on Java 1.7.0_40 Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM`. 

I've just tried with `Leiningen 2.3.2 on Java 1.7.0_40 Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM` and the problem doesn't reoccur on that version. Maybe this is a non-issue?

xumingming:

The patch is already merged.

Subtasks:

- STORM-654
- STORM-655
- STORM-726

Subtasks:

- STORM-1345

- STORM-1347

caofangkun:

update zookeeper from version 3.3.3 to 3.4.5

xumingming:

Duplicated with https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/STORM-72
Even if it is a non-issue for recent releases of leiningen, I'd like to see it merged to preserve compatibility with older versions of leiningen. So I'm still +1

caofangkun:

StormSubmitter.java or Utils.readCommandLineOpts() shoud also do the number check:

https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/blob/master/storm-core/src/jvm/backtype/storm/StormSubmitter.java#L78
https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/blob/master/storm-core/src/jvm/backtype/storm/utils/Utils.java#L157

StormSubmitter.java
storm-core/src/jvm/backtype/storm/StormSubmitter.java
@@ -9,6 +9,7 @@
  import java.util.Map;
  import org.slf4j.Logger;
  import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
 +import org.apache.commons.lang.math.NumberUtils;
  import org.apache.thrift7.TException;
  import org.json.simple.JSONValue;
  
 @@ -59,6 +60,12 @@ public static void submitTopology(String name, Map stormConf, StormTopology topo
  }
  stormConf = new HashMap(stormConf);
  stormConf.putAll(Utils.readCommandLineOpts());
     +  for (Object confName : stormConf.keySet()) {
     +    String confValue = String.valueOf(stormConf.get(confName));
     +    if (NumberUtils.isNumber(confValue)) {
     +      stormConf.put(confName, NumberUtils.createNumber(confValue));
     +    }
     +  }
  Map conf = Utils.readStormConfig();
  conf.putAll(stormConf);
  try {

caofangkun:

Collect process cpu use percent

ptgoetz:

I'm not sure how I feel about adding another native library requirement.

Why not use a monitoring tool like ganglia to accomplish this?

caofangkun:

P. Taylor Goetz
Currently, Storm provide LoggingMetricsConsume to collect metrics and just write to $STROM_HOME/logs/metric.log on the workers running machines.
But I find it's inconvenient to use the metric logs. So I just think writing metrics to DBs ,it's useful for my monitoring system and it's enough for me to analysis the nodal load of workers.
Writing metrics to DBs is simply a matter of choice , it's enough for some usage scenarios but it's not best for all usage scenarios.

And well , I have thinked about sending metrics to Ganglia.And I'm just thinking about how to combine Ganglia with my monitoring system.
(I just create a issue on this : https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/STORM-178 )

Thanks @davidlao2k, updated pull request.

revans2:

Ganglia works but it does not always correlate the CPU usage etc. with the exact worker process that is using it. So it cannot aggregate them by topology etc.

There are other places we can go to get CPU metrics that do not have native dependencies.

But really what it comes down to is that it would be nice to have a plug-in mechanism so that others can play around with worker level metrics. Similar to how we want to have worker wide resource initialization. For example I may have a cache shared by all the workers in this process, and having a system wide metric to monitor this cache would be great.

ptgoetz:

I agree with Bobby that something like this should be done via some kind of plug-in mechanism/API.

caofangkun:

Thanks Robert Joseph Evans
I was actually planning to use UnixOperatingSystemMXBean to get CPU metrics.
But there're two reasons for me not using it:
1: It provides too few APIs
2: it provides these APIs since 1.7 (As a matter of fact, all my machines use JDK 1.6.0_45)

And "provide a plug-in mechanism for others to play around with worker level metrics"
is really a good idea , I will think about it fully and carefully.
I see. +1 then. I normally just open up jetty to serve static files off a directory and copy the ui files there. I like yours better. Thanks.

One last change to get multilang working. `storm.cmd` was resetting the PATH variable, clobbering any user additions (such as the path to the `python` binary). So I changed it to just inherit any existing PATH value:

```
set path=%PATH%;...
```

I think this is good to go now.

+1

revans2:

Awesome. And please do make a CPU metrics plug-in open source somewhere, otherwise I'll be forced to write my own

Looks like it's in maven central now (as of 12/15/2013): http://search.maven.org/#search%7Cga%7C1%7Ca%3A%22jgrapht-core%22

Would you mind verifying and closing the pull request?
Yup, verified. 0.9.0 is found now. Closing this pull request. Thanks :-)

quies_net:

Hi James,

If you define the input fields for spouts then the stream groupings can be calculated (without configuration).
The implementation below does exactly that.

https://github.com/internet-research-network/breeze/blob/master/src/main/resources/eu/icolumbo/breeze/namespace/breeze-1.0.xsd
https://github.com/internet-research-network/breeze/blob/master/src/main/java/eu/icolumbo/breeze/build/TopologyCompilation.java

revans2:

How many zookeeper nodes did you have down out of how many total? Looking at the stack trace it is caused by curator saying it took too long for zookeeper to connect to the ensemble and it timed out. In this case it is waiting for Zookeeper to call back into the watcher to say that it has syncConnected. So this may be an issue with zookeeper, or curator has missed some other connection mode, or it could be that you actually don't have a full quorum and zk is doing the correct thing and not connecting. Say you have 2 zk nodes and one of them is down.

yerenkow:

In this log I have 3 zk servers in config and one available.

Maybe if it's feature - make logs look a bit clearer on what happened?

dagit:

https://github.com/apache/incubator-storm/pull/11

_If_ we end up moving to maven (per discussion on dev@storm.incubator.apache.org) we could probably use the maven jarjar plugin: https://github.com/sonatype/jarjar-maven-plugin

If we stick with Leiningen, we'd have to either stick with the shell script approach (which I'm not a fan of), or develop a Leiningen jarjar plugin.

+1

Great job @d2r ! This will be very helpful, especially for the new users.

dagit:

https://github.com/apache/incubator-storm/pull/12

revans2:

For a ZK quorum to be met you need to have more then 50% of the servers up and available. This is a ZK feature. If you want to file a JIRA under ZOOKEEPER or CURATOR that would be the correct place for this error message to come out. From the storm perspective we have little knowledge as to why curator threw the exception. I suppose we could try to do some detective work after we get the exception, but curator seems like a better place to do that.

revans2:

I don't have permission to close this, if one of the committers could close this issue or if you prefer we could try to forward it to CURATOR instead.

revans2:

My only issue here is that we really would want to back up the kill -15 with a kill -9 a little while later. We cannot be sure that the process is down unless we use the -9. But this would either mean that we have to wait a certain amount of time no matter what in between the two calls or we need a way to check if the process is still up. I can see the check being added in later if needed, but I don't want to rely on user code to always exit cleanly when asked politely.
I love seeing the help be directly in the UI.  +1
The changes look good to me.  It is sad you have to call e.get_msg, to get the error message out of the exception.  +1

mauzhang:

try to set "storm.messaging.netty.max_retries" to a smaller number (e.g. 10). The current setting will cause sleep_time to exceed the maximum integer and evaluate to a negative value.

boneill42:

+1, I agree with all the comments. This is clunky. It forces DRPC topologies into having a CLI-like layer on them.
good job

@revans2 What are the steps to reproduce that? I tried different versions of clojure (1.5) but didn't see any difference.

jihonrado:

Hi,

Thanks for the response. Now I am not getting the mentioned error but the topology is not working. I see to much traces like this:

2014-01-02 16:29:40 b.s.m.n.Client [INFO] Reconnect ... [10]
2014-01-02 16:29:40 b.s.m.n.Client [WARN] Remote address is not reachable. We will close this client.

Any idea?

Thanks

For me all I did was try to build, because I ran into the issue where trying to import a java class generated by clojure does not work in all cases on all computers, and I had to add in a use for that class before the import.

```
(:use [backtype.storm LocalDRPC])
```

But then I tried to reproduce it with other errors and the errors came out just fine.  So I rescind it being a blocker, it appears that it only happens in a few corner cases where the error causes the clojure compiler to crash with an exception that is not printed out.  I also tried clojure 1.5.1 and got the same result, but 1.6.0-alpha3 appears to have my fix in.  Not that we should move to that release, just that the corner case will be fixed eventually.
Just as a side note, all of the unit tests pass with 1.6.0-alpha3 :)

I also have found a couple of annoyances/regressions compared to the lein build. Not blockers but we should document them and look at ways to fix them.

```
mvn test
```

fails with

```

```
mvn package -Dtest=backtype.storm.cluster-test -DfailIfNoTests=false
```

Still runs all of the tests.  It looks like there may be a way to configure something like this using <testDeclaredNamespaceOnly>true</testDeclaredNamespaceOnly>, but it may take some work to make it seamlessly configurable via the command line.

Also test failures don't seem to fail the build (I modified a test to always fail)

```
mvn clean package
...

Thanks @revans2 . Yeah, the JIRA ticket erroneously states that the fix was included in 1.5 but it wasn't. The fix first appears in 1.6.0-alpha1.

1.5.1: https://github.com/clojure/clojure/blob/clojure-1.5.1/src/jvm/clojure/lang/Compile.java
1.6.0-alpha1: https://github.com/clojure/clojure/blob/clojure-1.6.0-alpha1/src/jvm/clojure/lang/Compile.java

The `java.lang.ClassNotFoundException` error only seems to happen if you run `mvn test` from the top level. If you run from `storm-core` everything is fine. I can probably fix this -- for some reason it's not picking up the shaded thrift dependency when run from the top level.

I can also confirm your other two points.

I'll do some digging with the maven-clojure-plugin to see if I can find a workaround or a fix.

Looking at the poms the rest looks OK.  I am +1 on this assuming that we file some JIRAs to address the issues I saw, or we can work around them some how.

After this patch we more or less are deprecating the fork of thrift that we have used up to now as a runtime dependency, but if we change the thrift definition we still need it for generating the java and python code.  Are there any plans to move to using the standard libthrift to generate the code as well?  And then perhaps use shade to modify the generated code to point to the shaded thrift7?

As a temporary workaround for running individual test suites, the easiest way is probably to do so through the REPL:

```
mvn clojure:repl
user=> (use 'clojure.test)
user=> (use 'backtype.storm.cluster-test)
user=> (run-tests 'backtype.storm.cluster-test)
```

For the build not failing on test failures, it seems to be an issue with using `clojure:test-with-junit` vs. `clojure:test`. With test failures, the former will succeed while the later won't.

I'll continue digging to figure out why.

@revans2 

> After this patch we more or less are deprecating the fork of thrift that we have used up to now as a runtime dependency, but if we change the thrift definition we still need it for generating the java and python code. Are there any plans to move to using the standard libthrift to generate the code as well? And then perhaps use shade to modify the generated code to point to the shaded thrift7?

Good question. Since the generated code is checked in to SCM, I was thinking it would be a manual process to regenerate the code (using standard thrift) and replace `org.apache.thrift` with `org.apache.thrift7`. But I'm open to suggestions. What do you think?

There have been a few fixes that have gone into our version of thrift7 that are not in the base thrift 7 (because it is so old it is no longer maintained), most notably was a fix for python that dealt with hash not being done correctly.  But I believe that there may be others too.  For now I would propose that we generate the code with the forked tool and file a JIRA to upgrade to a newer version of thrift to avoid this maintainability issue.

panfeng412:

yea, now the realization is quite naked. I describe some suggestions for DRPC client. Firstly, there is a pool named 'DPCClientPool' which realizes the reuse of TTransport. Secondly, it is better this pool can hide different DRPC servers with auto load balance, maybe like new DPCClientPool("drpc.server1,drpc.server2,drpc.server3").

@revans2 
Re: thrift7 -- I think that's a good plan for now. The Storm thrift API does not change that often so I think it is okay. Do you know where that fork lives? It would be good to know what was changed in that fork so we can compare it against newer thrift versions.

Also, I was able to confirm that there is an issue with the maven-clojure-plugin, specifically with `clojure:test-with-junit`. If there are test suites with failures among ones that pass, the plugin may not fail the build.

I submitted a quick fix:

https://github.com/talios/clojure-maven-plugin/pull/75

In the meantime, we can work around it by using `clojure:test` instead of `clojure:test-with-junit`. The only difference is that with `clojure:test` we would not get clojure tests in the maven test report, but that is not a big deal.

Compilation failed: Subprocess failed

The difference is that A attempts to compile the clojure packages in a different order than B. A starts with backtype.storm.bootstrap, while B starts with storm.trident.testing.

The solution is to add an explicit require (see patch).

Since the patch does not affect any functionality, I think it is safe to apply to avoid the issue on systems that behave like B.

I added the fix for [STORM-156](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/STORM-156) since it will likely affect some people (see the JIRA for an explanation).

I also switched from `clojure:test-with-junit` to `clojure:test` so the build will fail when there are test failures. We can switch back when the maven-clojure-plugin is fixed.

ptgoetz:

The numbers are correct. The difference is that in 0.9.0 Storm defaults the number of ackers to be equal to the number of workers (each acker uses an executor).

So for your word count topology, adding up the parallelism you get:

5 + 8 + 12 = 25

Then add 3 for the number of workers/ackers:

25 + 3 = 28

So the numbers are correct.

ptgoetz:

Storm does not (and likely will not) support this kind of functionality.

That being said, you can certainly implement this yourself. I would suggest using zookeeper for inter-component communication.

It's old, but you may be able to glean some of the concepts necessary from this project: https://github.com/ptgoetz/storm-signals

ptgoetz:

Currently the way to customize logging configuration is to modify $STORM_HOME/logback/cluster.xml

The log viewer daemon depends on that file to be able to find and display worker logs. Overriding it would break the log viewer functionality.

ptgoetz:

Merged for 0.9.1-incubating.

ptgoetz:

This has been fixed in 0.9.1-incubating.

ptgoetz:

Without version information and steps to reproduce, there's not much we can do. I'm going to close this.

ptgoetz:

This behavior is typically caused by doing something with STDOUT like enabling GC logging without directing it to a file. It can also happen with some logging configurations that log to CONSOLE.

I would suggest turning off GC logging or making sure that it is properly directed to a file. If you have altered the logging settings, I would try reverting to the default settings that Storm comes with.

The corresponding pull request for this issue was already merged.

jmlogan:

This brings up all sorts of inconvenient issues. If you are unable to trust your users on your network, what about DRPC calls? Should those also be protected? What about using the Storm-CLI? Shouldn't those also be protected?

ptgoetz:

Jon logan: Yes, all good points. An important upcoming focus area for storm is security, which is why I upped the priority.

In the near future, expect to see new JIRA tickets for everything you mentioned (and likely more).
